results.title: Clubbed to death
results.creator_credit: Yolande Zauberman, Alain Massiot and Madar
results.brief_description: Set in the outskirts of Paris, “Clubbed to death” offers a fresh perspective of the rave culture by setting it’s story amongst the Arab and African immigrant community that populate these poorer suburbs and vibrant dance scene. Elodie Bouchez (‘Dream life of angels’(1998), ‘Wild reeds’ (1994)) plays Lola, a 20 year-old club kid who falls asleep on the bus home one night and wakes to find herself in the middle of a popular night spot where local Arab and African teenagers go to party. On this eventful evening Lola pops an E and meets and falls in love with a boxer called Emir (Roschdy Zem). Like Alice in wonderland finding herself on the other side of the rabbit hole, the drugged out Lola must overcome various obstacles and opponents before she can be with her man. Her biggest hurdle’s are Emir’s vampy girlfriend and club podium dancer Saida (Beatrice Dalle), whose love for him borders on the obsessive, and Emir’s own struggle with heroin addiction. Director Yolande Zauberman chooses to treat this twilight world in a naturalistic, unflashy way through the use of hand held camera but heightens the visuals and narrative through the impressive electronic soundtrack which includes dance artists such as Massive Attack, Daft Punk and the Chemical Brothers. In French with English subtitles. Cast also includes Richard Courchet, Gerald Thomassin and Julie Bataille.

results.title: Sweet sweetback's baadasssss song (E)
results.brief_description: Starring the Black Community and directed, scripted, edited and produced by Melvin Van Peebles, “Sweet Sweetback’s Baadasssss Song” is one of the most influential of American underground/independent films. Influenced by the radical turn in the civil rights movement, and the resulting rise of the Black Panthers, “Sweet Sweetback …” makes no apologies for its revolutionary ardour. The police in this film are racist and corrupt, white people are murderous and the black population of the United States are still economic and cultural “slaves” to the “Man”. The film’s controversial and subversive power comes from suggesting that the very criminality and sexual licentiousness that racists have associated with the “African”, may be the very qualities the black population can use against their oppressors. Sweetback is a hustler, raised in a brothel. Picked up by the police one night, he snaps when the police begin brutalising a young revolutionary. For the rest of the film, Sweetback is running; running away from a racist America that will not tolerate an “uppity nigger”. Sly, fast and often cruelly funny, the film was made on a miniscule budget and is now unmistakably a result of the counter-cultural ferment of the late sixties. Van Peebles’s work is a pioneering work of Afro-American cinema, and though often considered a precursor to blaxploitation, it is a defiantly angry and passionate work. Features an acid funk music score by Earth, Wind and Fire. The video includes the movie’s original trailer as well as an interview with Van Peebles filmed in the late nineties.

results.title: The Mother and the whore = La Maman et la putan
results.creator_credit: Jean Eustache, Pierre Cottrell, V.M. Productions, Simar Films, Les Films du Losange, Cine Qua Non and Elite Films
results.brief_description: Jean-Pierre Leaud is a young intellectual who has relationships with two very different women, the faithful Marie and the promiscuous Veronika. “The Mother and the Whore” is an exploration of contemporary sexual relationships which concentrates on the bohemian subcultures of the disillusioned left. Dialogue, argument and dialect are what this film focuses upon, allowing for a candid and radical re-examination of the meaning of commitment and desire, as well as examining the often cataclysmic effects of feminism on gender roles and expectations. Winner of the Special Jury Prize at the 1973 Cannes Film Festival, “The Mother and the Whore” remains one of the most important and most admired of “Nouvelle Vague” cinema. The irony being, of course, is that in its detached over-view of the games between men and women, and in it’s ruthless mocking of the insularity of the French intelligentsia, the film initiates a clear break with the passionate and romantic idealism of the sixties new wave.

results.title: The Long walk of Nelson Mandela
results.creator_credit: Clifford Bestall, Indra de Langerolle, David Fanning, Unapix Entertainment Productions, LLC and Story Street Productions
results.brief_description: This is an intimate portrait of one of the century’s greatest leaders told by those who have known and shared the more important moments of his life. However it is not just a narrative of Mandela’s life, its purpose is to examine how Mandela has risen above his very public personal trials and kept his eye unflinchingly on a distant and noble goal. Mandela’s life story and achievements are told through interviews with his contemporaries and friends and the use of archival footage.

results.title: Daleks: invasion Earth 2150 A.D. [Widescreen]
results.brief_description: Based on a story from the BBC TV serial “Doctor Who”, Dr. Who and his companions arrive on Earth in the year 2150 AD, only to discover that the planet has been invaded and its population enslaved by the dreaded Daleks. The time travellers assist human resistance groups to foil the Daleks’ plan to mine the Earth’s core.

results.title: Last stand at Saber River
results.creator_credit: Dick Lowry, Steven Brandman, Thomas Kane, Mary Ann Braubach, Turner Entertainment and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: An embittered Confederate soldier returns to his Arizona homestead after the end of the Civil War, only to find it occupied by pioneers sympathetic to the Union war effort. Desperate to rebuild the life he once knew, he is forced to re-consider his loyalties and join forces with his Union adversary to make a last stand for the one thing left worth fighting for - his family.

results.title: Labyrinth
results.creator_credit: Jim Henson, Eric Rattray and Lucasfilm, Ltd.
results.brief_description: Take a journey into the Labyrinth, where nothing is as it seems. Sarah (Jennifer Connelly) spends most of her time play-acting scenes from her favourite book, The Labyrinth, or baby-sitting her younger brother, Toby. One night, frustrated with Toby’s incessant crying, she begs the goblins to take him away. When Toby actually disappears, Sarah follows him into the world of the wicked Goblin King (David Bowie), where she is given thirteen hours to conquer the Labyrinth, before her baby brother is turned into a goblin forever. An engaging fantasy film, populated by creatures created by Jim Henson’s Creature Shop, and drawing inspiration from a number of sources, including the works of Brian Froud, Maurice Sendak and M. C. Escher. Includes a special behind-the-scenes featurette detailing the making of Labyrinth.

results.title: O' Lucky man
results.creator_credit: Lindsay Anderson, Michael Medwin, Sam, Memorial and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Director Lindsay Anderson delivers a film that consciously plays with the telling of a story, beginning with sepia tone and the opening line ‘Once Upon a Time’. From then on we’re launched into technicolour and taken on the surreal journey of an ambitious young man in search of success who is constantly thwarted by the British Establishment. Mick Travis (Malcolm McDowell), a trainee coffee salesman, is both optimistic and naive. With his desire to be successful he eagerly jumps at any opportunity with wilful ignorance that inevitably leads him into the path of sinister digressions that challenge his good intentions. Each vignette plays on the genres of film from horror to comedy, realism to surrealism. The actors deftly play several roles each, their characters weave in and out of the story line to occasionally reconnect in this sprawling celebration of allegory.

results.title: The Eel = Unagi
results.creator_credit: Shohei Imamura, Hisa Lino, Imamura Productions, KSS Films, Satellite Cinema and Shochiku
results.brief_description: The Eel begins with the main character - Takuro Yamashita (Koji Yakusho) coming home early from a fishing trip to catch his wife committing adultery. He stabs her to death and then hands himself in to the police. The credits to the film commence, where it is revealed that Yamashita has just been released after eight years in prison. He carries with him a pet eel who has been his main companion in prison. Yamashita buys a dilapidated barber shop in a small rural town where he assumes he will be left alone. Soon, however, he is befriended by the assorted local characters who hang around his shop. Then he saves the life of Keiko Hattori (Misa Shimizu), a woman attempting to commit suicide to escape her manipulative fiance and her mad mother - and who also happens to resemble his murdered wife. The lives of these two escapees soon become entwined. Winner of the 1997 Cannes Palme d’Or, Shohei Imamura’s film masterfully balances humour and surreal imagery with a tale of redemption and love. The film bristles with the tension of Yamashita’s constant potential for violence and the surprising comical twists of his journey. In Japanese with English subtitles.

results.title: Chronicle of a love = Loving lie
results.brief_description: Antonioni’s highly acclaimed first film relates the tale of an adulterous wife and her impoverished lover who plan to murder her rich husband. He dies before they carry out the deed and they have to live with the guilt of their intentions. In Italian with English subtitles.
results.description: Antonioni’s highly acclaimed first film relates the tale of an adulterous wife and her impoverished lover who plan to murder her rich husband. He dies before they carry out the deed and they have to live with the guilt of their intentions. In Italian with English subtitles.
